title: My family say I'm a monster for not donating kidney to sister - Daily Express US
text: 'My family think I'm a monster for refusing to donate my kidney to my sister' A woman is in a difficult position after discovering she is her sister's only hope of survival - but she fears the impact donating a kidney could have on her. A woman faces a heart-wrenching dilemma that could spell disaster for either [her or her sister,](/lifestyle/life/145475/my-family-monster-not-donating-kidney-sister) and she's taken to [kidney](/latest/kidney-cancer) failure, and the doctors have made it clear that a transplant is essential for her survival. The [younger sibling](/lifestyle/parenting/144900/my-mom-pregnant-has-stolen-name-i-wanted-call-my-future-daughter?utm_source=mynewsassistant.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=embedded_search_item_mobile) is the only match in their family. Their [relationship has been rocky](#), with the ['I've been planning my baby's name since I was 12 â€” Then my brother stole it'](/lifestyle/parenting/144559/ive-been-planning-my-babys-name-since-i-was-12-my-brother-stole-it) [Pharmacy worker astonished as mom legally changes son's name to unique moniker](/lifestyle/life/144277/mom-legally-changes-baby-name) Complicating matters further, the 19-year-old has health concerns of her own, making the prospect of major surgery potentially harmful. Torn by her predicament, she shared: "When I found out I'm the only possible donor, I felt overwhelmed. I've tried talking to my family about my reservations, but they insist that it's my duty to save her because we're family." Her sister has expressed deep disappointment, suggesting that a refusal to donate would be proof of her lack of care: "My sister is understandably upset and has been telling me that if I don't donate, it proves I don't care about her." Amidst accusations from her family that withholding her kidney would make her a terrible person, the young woman is caught between not wanting her sister to die and protecting her own well-being. In the comments, individuals who have experienced kidney donation firsthand weighed in. One commenter offered advice, saying: "Tell the transplant team you are being coerced to donate. They will then tell your family you are ineligible to donate. They will not say why because of HIPAA if you're in the States. Most countries have similar rules." Another pointed out that health concerns might prevent her from being cleared to donate by a doctor. A different user highlighted additional considerations, noting that some research indicates increased risks for women who become pregnant after donating a kidney, even if they are in perfect health.
